 That is because she crossed the line from "quasi legal" to entirely illegal, and she did it in such a manner that she handed the evidence to the prosecution on a silver platter.
 
 In the US, personal responsibility has disapeared from corporate officers. Unless you can prove an overt criminal act, personally carried out by the officer in question, there is really no hope of a conviction. It is the "just a cog in the bigger machine" defense.
 
 Corporate officers know this, and generally avoid personally doing anything illegal (i.e they send somebody else out to dump the toxic waste on the schoolyard). I think that when they actually DO catch a corporate officer in the middle of something they can prosecute them for, it gives the prosecutors and the judges a woody.
